Description: Rim sherd (mended from four fragments, with 1924,1201.353) of Chian black-figured Komast pottery chalice; white slip; interior: reserved band at rim, glazed streaky black below; exterior: diagonal strokes between bands around rim; below, black-figure decoration consisting of female figure to left (head with added red hair and raised arm holding pomegranate remaining); pendant incised rosette with red centre as filling ornament.
Curator's comments: The sherd joins British Museum 1924,1201.353. A number of Chian chalices from Emporio (Lemos no. 1468) and Rizari (Lemos no, 1487) depict komast dancers alongside female figures dressed in long chitons and playing the double flute and tambourine (or possibly holding a wreath). Occasionally, the female figure is holding a pomegranate. On some chalices, the female figures are incised whilst on others, they are depicted in outline. The figures on the sherds from Naukratis are likely to be from similar scenes interpreted as dancers following and performing with a chorus of women.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GD.1262) (phase 2)
Williams 1983 / Sophilos in the British Museum (p. 162 note 25)
